title: Coat of arms of Portugal
text:
The coat of arms of Portugal is the main heraldic insignia of Portugal. The present model was officially adopted on 30 June 1911, along with the present model of the <a href="Flag%20of%20Portugal">Flag of Portugal</a>. It is based on the coat of arms used by the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Portugal">Portuguese Kingdom</a> since the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>. The coat of arms of Portugal is popularly referred as the Quinas (a "quina" being a group of five things).
History and evolution.
The national heraldry of Portugal evolved from the royal heraldry, with the royal coat of arms gradually coming to be considered a national coat of arms.
The Portuguese coat of arms itself is the result of almost a millennium of modifications and alterations. Starting with the cross "azur" on field "argent", which constituted the putative shield of <a href="Henry%2C%20Count%20of%20Portugal">Henry</a>, <a href="Count%20of%20Portugal">Count of Portugal</a> in the 12th century, successive elements were added or taken, culminating with the complex heraldic design that was officially adopted in 1911 (after the <a href="Portuguese%20First%20Republic">Republican Revolution</a> of 1910).
Evolution.
The main and constant element of the coat of arms of Portugal is and has always been the Portuguese shield. This resulted from around 300 years of evolution, from the 12th to the 15th centuries.
The heraldic shield used by <a href="Afonso%20Henriques">Afonso Henriques</a>, who became the first King of Portugal, is believed to have been "Argent, a cross azure" (a blue cross on a white field), apparently the same as that used by his father, Count Henry.
The original shield evolved to "Argent, five escutcheons crosswise the dexter and sinister ones pointing to the center azure each semée of plates" (a field "argent" with five <a href="Escutcheon%20%28heraldry%29">escutcheon</a>s "azure" forming a cross, the "dexter" and "sinister" ones pointing to the center, with each escutcheon "<a href="sem%C3%A9e">semée</a>" of <a href="Roundel_%28heraldry%29%23Terms_for_roundels">plates</a>). This is the earliest verifiable form of the Portuguese shield. Apparently it was introduced during the reign of Afonso Henriques (Afonso I) and definitely was used during the reign of his successor King <a href="Sancho%20I%20of%20Portugal">Sancho I</a> (1185-1211), during the period in which heraldry came into widespread use throughout western Europe.
Iconography.
There are several legends which seek to explain the significance of the five escutcheons and of the plates. The escutcheons are said to represent either the <a href="Five%20Holy%20Wounds">Five Holy Wounds</a> of Christ on the Cross, the five wounds suffered by Afonso Henriques in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Ourique">Battle of Ourique</a> or the five Moorish kings defeated by him in that battle. The plates are supposed to represent either the <a href="thirty%20pieces%20of%20silver">pieces of silver</a> received by <a href="Judas%20Iscariot">Judas Iscariot</a> to betray Jesus or the sovereignty of the Portuguese Kings, symbolized by the right to issue their own money. A more mundane theory suggests that the heraldry represents merely the physical fabric of the battle-<a href="shield">shield</a> of Afonso Henriques, which may have comprised two blue leather bands nailed to a white base; after having been being repeatedly hit in battle, most of the bands had become cut off, except for the five pieces on top of the clusters of <a href="Nail%20%28fastener%29">nails</a>. These remaining five pieces of blue leather with the bright heads of the nails showing through, are thus proposed as the origin of the five escutcheons "azur", each "semée" of plates.
Bordure.
When the future <a href="Afonso%20III%20of%20Portugal">Afonso III of Portugal</a> asserted his claim to the throne occupied by his brother Sancho II, he adopted as his coat of arms the Portuguese shield <a href="Difference%20%28heraldry%29">differenced</a> by the addition of a bordure "gules semée of castles or". When Afonso III eventually became King in 1247, he retained use of this differenced shield, instead of reverting to the original shield without the bordure. There are several theories which seek to explain the significance of the castles within the bordure, the most popular one being that they represent the last castles conquered in the Algarve from the Moors by that king, completing the Portuguese "<a href="Reconquista">Reconquista</a>". However, the most common presently accepted theory is that the bordure was merely a mark of <a href="cadency">cadency</a> to signify that Afonso was not the head of the Royal family, the castles probably having been suggested as suitable elements from the <a href="Heraldry%20of%20Castile">arms</a> of his mother <a href="Urraca%20of%20Castile%2C%20Queen%20of%20Portugal">Urraca of Castile</a>. Later the number of castles within the bordure became fixed at seven, this being the version of the shield still in use today.
Cross of Aviz.
During the <a href="1383%E2%80%931385%20Portuguese%20interregnum">1383–1385 Portuguese interregnum</a>, one of the emerging candidates to the throne was <a href="John%20I%20of%20Portugal">John</a>, master of the <a href="Order%20of%20Aviz">Order of Aviz</a>, an illegitimate son of King <a href="Peter%20I%20of%20Portugal">Peter I of Portugal</a>. John was elected Regent and Defender of Kingdom in 1383 and <a href="Acclamation">acclaimed</a> King of Portugal in 1385, as <a href="John%20I%20of%20Portugal">John I</a> and during his reign the royal Portuguese shield was added to by the inclusion of the insignia of the Order of Aviz, namely a " cross flory vert" (a green cross with a <a href="fleur-de-lys">fleur-de-lys</a> at the end of each arm). This was effected in various ways: by insertion within the bordure, alternating with the castles; more commonly inserted within the shield, and occasionally shown outside the shield with the latter laying over it.
Escutcheons erected.
Finally, in 1485, King <a href="John%20II%20of%20Portugal">John II</a> ordered the correction of the Portuguese shield, eliminating features identified as heraldic errors. Thus the cross of the Order of Aviz was removed and the "<a href="Dexter%20and%20sinister">dexter</a>" and "<a href="Dexter%20and%20sinister">sinister</a>" escutcheons were set upright, lest left couchée they might be assumed to symbolize bastardy, which was not appropriate in the case of that monarch. Furthermore, the "semée" of plates on the field of each of the five escutcheons was fixed in number at five as a reference to the <a href="Five%20Holy%20Wounds">Five Holy Wounds</a> of <a href="Christ">Christ</a>, being the personal devotion of that monarch, and were arranged in saltire thus forming a <a href="quincunx">quincunx</a>. Thus, the arrangement of five escutcheons, each with five plates started to be known as "quinas", signifying "groups of five", and by <a href="synecdoche">synecdoche</a>, the Portuguese shield itself started to be referred as the "quinas".
During some periods of effective or claimed Royal union of Portugal with other states, the Portuguese shield was used marshaled with the coats of arms of those states. <a href="Beatrice%20of%20Portugal">Beatrice of Portugal</a>, who claimed the Portuguese crown during the 1383-1385 interregnum, used the Portuguese arms in the II and III positions of the shield, marshaled with the arms of her husband King <a href="John%20I%20of%20Castile">John I of Castile</a> in the I and IV. King <a href="Afonso%20V%20of%20Portugal">Afonso V of Portugal</a>, who claimed the <a href="crown%20of%20Castile">crown of Castile</a> during the 1475-1479 period, used the Portuguese arms in the I and IV, marshaled with the <a href="Coat%20of%20arms%20of%20Castile%20and%20Le%C3%B3n">arms of Castile and León</a> in the II and III. During the period of the <a href="Iberian%20Union">Iberian Union</a> (1580-1640), the Portuguese shield was placed in the honour point of the complex coat of arms of the <a href="House%20of%20Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a>. These marshaled coats of arms had, however, a very limited use, with the simple Portuguese coat of arms being used in the national context and the marshaled arms being only used when they intended to represent personally the monarch.
When the status of <a href="Colonial%20Brazil">Brazil</a> was raised from that of state to a constituent kingdom of the Portuguese Monarchy, giving origin to the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Portugal%2C%20Brazil%20and%20the%20Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>, the Royal coat of arms was altered by the addition of an armillary sphere "or" over a field "azur", these being the Brazilian arms. The new Royal achievement of arms consisted therefore of the Portuguese shield (representing Portugal and the Algarves) over the armillary sphere (representing Brazil), all topped by the Royal crown. Although displayed as a supporter of the Portuguese shield and not as part of it, it is controversial if the armillary sphere should be considered or not part of the main field of the new achievement. This achievement of arms was used in Portugal from 1815 to 1826 (despite Brazil having achieved independence in 1822, only when King <a href="John%20VI%20of%20Portugal">John VI</a> died in 1826 did Portugal revert to the use of the old coat of arms).
The elements surrounding the shield.
Until the early 14th century, the achievement of arms of Portugal consisted solely in the shield, with no external elements surrounding it being represented.
A crown over the shield started to appear in some representations of the Portuguese coat of arms in the 14th century. Initially, a crude open crown was represented, this evolving to a crown similar to the present <a href="coronet">coronet</a> of <a href="duke">duke</a>, so consisting of a circlet surmounted by leaves. The crown come to appear more and more in the representations of the coat of arms of Portugal, becoming virtually inseparable from the Portuguese shield. In most of the cases the crown was represented laying directly over the shield, although in the rare occasions in which the helmet was represented, the crown was placed over it. From the 16th century until the establishment of the republican coat of arms in 1910, the Royal crown was virtually present in all representations of the coat of arms of Portugal, being also the only constant external element of the shield. In the reign of <a href="Sebastian%20of%20Portugal">King Sebastian</a> (1557-1578), the open Royal crown was replaced by a crown closed with a single arch. This latter evolved to a crown with two arches. The final model of heraldic crown was adopted in the reign of <a href="Peter%20II%20of%20Portugal">Peter II</a> (1683-1706), this being a crown closed with four arches, surmounted by a globe topped with a cross. At the same time, the previous crown with two arches became the crown of the Prince apparent heir of the Portuguese crown.
Other external elements surrounding the shield, started to be also represented in the Portuguese coat of arms from the 14th century, although none of them has reached the status of a constant element, as the Royal crown.
One of the most important of these elements was the <a href="crest%20%28heraldry%29">heraldic crest</a>, which at least from the reign of John I became a <a href="dragon">dragon</a>, probably associated to the adoption of <a href="Saint%20George">Saint George</a> as the patron saint of Portugal. Until the 17th century, the dragon was represented in "or", but since then, it started to be represented in "vert". This change of color was probably due to the ascension to the throne, in 1640, of the <a href="House%20of%20Braganza">House of Braganza</a>, which had the <a href="green">green</a> as its <a href="livery">livery</a> color, this also becoming the national color of Portugal. During the period of the House of Braganza, two dragons "vert" became frequently used as the supporters of the Portuguese Royal shield.
Other of the external elements was the <a href="helmet%20%28heraldry%29">helmet</a> "or" with bars, that was frequently represented between the 14th and the 16th centuries, but rarely appearing in the achievement afterwards. Both the <a href="torse">torse</a> and the <a href="mantling">mantling</a> that appeared in the helmet were represented in "argent" and "gules" during the reign of King <a href="Manuel%20I%20of%20Portugal">Manuel I</a> (1495-1521), these being his livery colors. In latter representations of the Royal achievement of arms, the torse and the mantling included the four colors of the Portuguese shield "argent", "gules", "or" and "azur".
<a href="Supporters">Supporters</a> also were frequently represented in many artistic representations of the Portuguese coat of arms. The most frequently represented supporters until the 18th century were the angels. Usually two angels were represented, one in "dexter" and the other in "sinister", but in some representations the shield is supported by a single angel. Occasionally, the supporter angel was represented using a <a href="tabard">tabard</a> or <a href="surcoat">surcoat</a> with the Portuguese arms, what may indicate that he was not a generic angel but specifically the <a href="Guardian%20Angel%20of%20Portugal">Guardian Angel of Portugal</a>. From the reign of King Manuel I forward, it was common to represent the angels handling armillary spheres and <a href="cross%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20Christ">crosses of the Order of Christ</a> or handling <a href="flag">flag</a>s with those badges. From the 18th century onwards, the dragons "vert" that served as the Portuguese crest became also the most often represented supporters in the achievement of arms of Portugal. In latter representations of the Portuguese coat of arms, the dragons "dexter" and "sinister" carry each one a flag with elements of the Portuguese shield, the "dexter" being "argent" with the five escutcheons and the "sinister" being "gules" with seven castles "or".
In the reign of King Manuel I, his personal <a href="heraldic%20badge">heraldic badge</a> (the <a href="armillary%20sphere">armillary sphere</a>) and his insignia as master of the <a href="Order%20of%20Christ%20%28Portugal%29">Order of Christ</a> (the <a href="cross%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20Christ">cross of this order</a>) started be intensively represented, usually as elements surrounding the Portuguese shield. These two heraldic insignia were so intensively used that they evolved from being mere personal insignias of Manuel I to be considered national insignias, continuing to be used even after the end of the reign of this king. Occasionally, the armillary sphere was represented as the supporter of the Portuguese shield, in a similar composition to those that, centuries latter, would be used in the arms of the United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves and of the Portuguese Republic.
During the reign of <a href="Henry%20I%20of%20Portugal">Henry</a>, a peculiar Royal achievement of arms was used, which included a red ecclesiastical hat (<a href="galero">galero</a>) and respective tassels, combined with the Royal crown, to reflect the <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">cardinal</a> standing of the King.
During the 1815-1825 period, the Royal coat arms were changed to reflect the establishment of the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Portugal%2C%20Brazil%20and%20the%20Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>, starting to include also the <a href="armillary%20sphere">armillary sphere</a> "or" over a field "azur", which was adopted as the coat of arms of the newly created <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Brazil">Kingdom of Brazil</a>. The new achievement consisted so of the Portuguese shield (representing Portugal and the Algarve) over the armillary sphere (representing Brazil), all topped by the Royal crown. The armillary sphere appeared so as a kind of supporter of the shield, although it is controversial if it should be really considered a supporter or part of the main element of the arms.
From the second half of the 19th century, the Royal coat of arms became commonly represented with the shield covered by a <a href="Mantle%20%28vesture%29">pavilion</a> <a href="purple">purple</a> lined <a href="Ermine%20%28heraldry%29">ermine</a> issuing from the Royal crown.
The present model of the coat of arms.
The present model of the coat of arms of Portugal was designed by the painter <a href="Columbano%20Bordalo%20Pinheiro">Columbano</a>, member of the commission appointed on the 15 October 1910 to present the project for a new <a href="flag%20of%20Portugal">National Flag</a>, following the establishing of the <a href="Portuguese%20First%20Republic">Portuguese republic</a> on the 5 October 1910. The models chosen by the commission were approved by the Provisional Government of the Republic on the 29 November 1910, confirmed by the Constituent Assembly through the decree of 19 June 1911, with its details being specified in the "Diário do Governo" (official journal) no 150 of 30 June 1911.
Three versions of the coat of arms were established, intended for different types of use. All three include, as its central element, the shield of the traditional Portuguese arms placed over a golden armillary sphere.
The basic version consists of only the Portuguese shield over the armillary sphere. This version was intended to be used on the National Flag and on the naval jack. From the 23 September 1911, this version was also used on the naval distinctive flags of the President of the Republic, ministers and other state authorities, latter being also used on some governmental and state flags created afterwards. Occasionally, this version is unofficially referred as the "lesser arms of Portugal".
The second version consists of the Portuguese shield over the armillary sphere, with this being surrounded by two branches of laurel, tied in the base with a white scroll with the <a href="Lu%C3%ADs%20de%20Cam%C3%B5es">Camões</a> verse "Esta é a ditosa Pátria minha amada" (This is my beloved famous Motherland). This version was intended to be used on the regimental colors of the military units.
Finally, the third version is similar to the second one but the scroll does not include the verse and is usually represented in red and green. This version was intended to be used in <a href="seal%20%28emblem%29">seal</a>s, <a href="coin">coin</a>s and other <a href="emblem">emblem</a>s.
Present and past elements of the arms of Portugal.
"Quinas".
"Quina" (plural "quinas") is the <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a> term for a group of five things.
After the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Zamora">official recognition</a> of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Portugal">Kingdom of Portugal</a> as an independent country in 1143 (it had been self declared as so in 1139), silver <a href="bezant">bezant</a>s were added to the blue cross of the shield, symbolising coins and the right of the monarch to issue currency, as leader of a sovereign state. Eventually, and given the enormous dynamism of <a href="medieval">medieval</a> <a href="heraldry">heraldry</a>, it is believed that the shield degraded and lost some elements in battle, eventually losing the cross format. This is how King <a href="Sancho%20I%20of%20Portugal">Sancho I</a> inherited the shield from his father, <a href="Afonso%20Henriques">Afonso Henriques</a>, with the cross replaced by <a href="escutcheon%20%28heraldry%29">escutcheon</a>s with the silver bezants. A traditional legend explains that these escutcheons represent the five moor kings defeated by King <a href="Afonso%20I%20of%20Portugal">Afonso I of Portugal</a> in the <a href="battle%20of%20Ourique">battle of Ourique</a>.
The number of silver bezants in each escutcheon varied extensively, with versions having represented from four up to eleven. In the late 14th century however, the number of bezants was fixed in five. Late explanations interpret them as the five wounds of <a href="Jesus%20Christ">Jesus Christ</a> and/or the <a href="thirty%20pieces%20of%20silver">thirty pieces of silver</a> (with the five bezants in the middle escutcheon counted twice), although this is highly improbable.
From the fixation of the number of bezants in five, the groups of the five escutcheons, each with five bezants of the Portuguese shield became popularly referred as "quinas". By <a href="synecdoche">synecdoche</a>, the term "Quinas" came to be used as an alternative designation of the coat of arms of Portugal and came even be used as a reference to anything that represents Portugal (e.g. the Flag of Portugal being often referred as the "Flag of the "Quinas"").
Castles.
It was during the reign of <a href="Afonso%20III">Afonso III</a> that the red <a href="bordure">bordure</a> with golden castles (not towers, as some sources state) was added. Although the number of castles could vary between eight and twelve, <a href="Afonso%20IV">Afonso IV</a> would define them as twelve, and <a href="Sebastian%20I">Sebastian I</a> would finally fix them as seven. They supposedly represent the <a href="Moorish">Moorish</a> castles conquered by the Kingdom of Portugal during the <a href="Reconquista">Reconquista</a>. Their origin is probably <a href="Heraldry%20of%20Castile">Castilian</a>, but unlike Spanish castles, which usually have their gates coloured blue (hence opened), Portuguese castles were usually depicted with gold gates (hence closed). As a matter of fact, Afonso III was the second son of King <a href="Afonso%20II%20of%20Portugal">Afonso II of Portugal</a> and thus was not expected to inherit the throne, which was destined to go to his elder brother King <a href="Sancho%20II%20of%20Portugal">Sancho II of Portugal</a>. As a second son, the coat of arms of Afonso III included both the arms of his father and the arms of his mother Urraca of Castile, thus the Castillan red border with golden castillan castles, around the Portuguese shield inherited from his father.
Armillary sphere.
An important element of Portuguese heraldry since the 15th century, the <a href="armillary%20sphere">armillary sphere</a> was many times used in Portuguese naval and colonial flags, mainly in <a href="Colonial%20Brazil">Brazil</a>. It was a navigation instrument used to calculate distances and represents the importance of Portugal during the <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>, as well as the vastness of its colonial empire when the <a href="First%20Portuguese%20Republic">First Republic</a> was implemented.
Although it is commonly regarded as a "republican" element, as opposed to the monarchist crown in the blue/white flag (see <a href="Flag%20of%20Portugal">Flag of Portugal</a>), its usage predates the republic by several centuries; it was the personal emblem of Manuel I. Some flags of the monarchic era, such as the flag of the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Portugal%2C%20Brazil%20and%20the%20Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>, already depicted armillary spheres. The incorporation of the armillary sphere into the 1816 flag of the United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and Algarves is related to the adoption of the first flag of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Brazil">Kingdom of Brazil</a>, an armillary sphere on a blue background.
Crowns.
The coat of arms sported different crowns during imperial rule of Portuguese and foreign crowns.
